title: 110_hr4092
content: The Act titled "Mountaintown National Scenic Area Act of 2007" designates the Mountaintown National Scenic Area in the Chattahoochee National Forest, Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established in the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, covering approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit a final map and boundary description to Congress, with the map available for public inspection. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area in the Chattahoochee National Forest covers 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a final map and boundary description for public inspection. The management of the scenic area includes protecting and preserving scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and wildlife habitat. The Secretary will develop a management plan for the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within three years, prioritizing management purposes over general laws and regulations for the National Forest System. This plan will focus on preserving scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and wildlife habitat, while also promoting recreation opportunities. The management plan for the Chattahoochee National Forest prohibits new road construction within the scenic area, allows timber harvest only for fire, insect, and disease control, restricts motorized travel, and permits vegetation manipulation for wildlife clearings and visual quality maintenance. Firewood can be harvested for personal use along perimeter roads under specified conditions. The scenic area management plan prohibits new road construction, restricts motorized travel except for administrative use, authorizes fire suppression, controls insect and disease outbreaks, maintains water quality, and allows mining withdrawal with valid existing rights. Mining Withdrawal: All federally owned lands in the scenic area are withdrawn from mining laws and leasing claims, except for valid existing rights.
